transcripts.text: My next guest is the leader of the Brexit Party, Nigel Farage.  Good morning to you.  Good morning.  Good morning.  Now, you over the weekend reiterated with adverts in many national newspapers what you've been saying for a few days now is that you are offering an electoral pact to Boris Johnson's Conservative Party.  You'll stand down candidates in their seats where they're most likely to win.  They should stand down candidates in the seats where you're more likely to win.  And together, you reckon you could deliver a 100-strong majority vote for the Conservative Party and for Leave to deliver Brexit.  Have you had any response from the Conservative Party yet, Nigel?

No, I haven't.  But look, the logic's there.  It's very simple.  You know, if I was to say to Brexit Party voters and supporters and to really endorse candidates other than ours in the right constituencies, I think we could deliver a 60 to 100 majority.  Yeah, I genuinely do.  Look, out there in the country, Most people just want this over.  They want us to get on with the rest of our lives.  And so I've said, look, much as I'm immensely proud of what we've built in the Brexit party in the last 22 weeks, country before party at a moment like this so we can get some resolution on Brexit.  And it's up to Boris Johnson.  But there's one condition.  There's one condition, and the condition is we do not want any reheated form of Mrs May's withdrawal agreement.  It's the worst deal in history.  We want a clean break and to become an independent country.  And if Boris goes down that route, then I think it makes sense for us to work together.

OK, now today, let's talk about what's happening today in Parliament.  We're going to get royal assent for the bill, which is known by the Tories as the Surrender Bill, to actually stop us from leaving with a no-deal Brexit on October 31st, as the ticket on which Boris Johnson got himself elected as Tory leader and has promised the country he will do.  We're also expecting to have this vote to have another attempt at having a general election.  Boris Johnson is expected to lose that election.  Why do you think that the opposition parties want to avoid a general election right now?  Because, of course, Labour and the Lib Dems are saying, everyone's always talking about people's votes, are they not?  And they're always talking about how the country is opposed to no deal, is opposed to what the Tories are trying to do.  Why then do you think they're trying to stop that from happening?

Two reasons.  Firstly, because Labour would not win a majority or get anywhere near it if there was an election within the course of the next few weeks.  And secondly, they know something, which is this.  If this Conservative government doesn't take us out on the 31st of October, support for the Conservatives once again will collapse.  And I think the Labour Party cynically know that, so they're prepared.  to put party advantage above delivering on the promise of their own manifesto in 2017 when they said they would respect the result of the referendum.
Do you think we are going to get a general election either before October 31st or the end of the year?

I think there'll be a general election before the end of the year and I'll tell you why.  I was last week out round the north of England and I'll be out round the north of England again this week.  There are a lot of Labour voters saying, we've had enough of the Labour Party playing games in Westminster.  And this particularly coming from Leave voting constituencies in the Midlands and in the north of England.  And in the end, the pressure on Corbyn to go for an election will become too great.  So I think there will be a general election, not before the 31st of October, but before Christmas, absolutely.

But realistically, in terms of what happens before then, Boris Johnson has said he won't break the law.  They're trying to test the law.  There may be a Supreme Court case.  Who knows?  But he can't force a general election unless opposition parties are willing to do it.  He's lost so many MPs, his rebels and the like.  Even with the DUP, he doesn't have the votes.  What do you think the most likely outcome is in the coming weeks?  Because if Boris Johnson says, I'm not going to ask for this extension... Does that mean that he's going to resign, that there's going to be a vote of no confidence?  What's going to happen in your view?

I don't know.  But I think at some point, if Boris refuses to act on the legislation that Parliament has passed, Parliament will bring him down.  There will be a motion of confidence towards the end of October.  Parliament will bring him down.  That could mean a Corbyn caretaker government or, failing that, a general election.  Whichever way I look at this, we are going to have a general election before Christmas.

Now, in terms of doing a deal, you say there's been no response.  It may well be that Nigel Farage said that it's Boris Johnson who isn't ready for a pact.  It doesn't want anything to be talked about.  It may well also be that there's no love lost, let's be honest, between you and Dominic Cummings.  Now, the Prime Minister's chief advisor, he was in charge of the Vote Leave campaign.  You were in the rival Leave.eu campaign.  We know some of us just from that documentary starring, docudrama starring Benedict Cumberbatch, that there is no love lost between you and Dominic Cummings.  Could that be the thing that is stopping a deal happening?  In which case, does Boris Johnson need to get rid of Dominic Cummings before there can be a deal?

Well, Dominic Cummings, I mean, over the last few years, he's not just me he's been against, he's been against the ERG as well.  Cummings has always been against.  what he would have seen as hardline leavers, and yet he now appears to be the man behind Boris Johnson, you know, pushing a message that we'll leave with no deal if we can't improve the current one.  So maybe Dominic Cummings' politics has changed over the course of the last three or four years.  I don't know.  But ultimately, you know, if you add up in the opinion polls where the Tories are, where the Brexit Party are, and put them together, all right, not every one of those voters will come across.  But even if you take a bit off the top of both, Together, in a pact, in a general election, we would be unstoppable.  And ultimately, whatever Dominic Cummings' personal traits may be, he's no fool.

At the end of the day, there'll be lots of people on the Leave side who will say, look, you started the Brexit party because Theresa May was in power and she was trying to deliver a pretence brino, Brexit in name only, Brexit without a withdrawal agreement.  And the Brexit party was started, you won the European elections in May because you were offering a proper Brexit, a no-deal, a clean Brexit.  Probably happy to have a deal, a free trade agreement or something, but something, a proper Brexit that people who voted in 2016 would recognise as being what they voted for.  Now you've got a Prime Minister, now you've got a leader of the Conservative Party, you know that two-thirds of the Tory party members and two-thirds of Tory MPs voted for a man who said he will deliver, deal or no deal, do or die, a proper Brexit.  Some would say, isn't it time for you to stand aside completely?  Forget an electoral pact.  Time for you and the Brexit party to stand aside, give the Tory party a free reign.  We know that that leave vote is split between the two parties.  If you walked away, those people would have no choice but to vote for the Tory party who can deliver Brexit.  So a vote for the Brexit party right now might actually be the vote that stops Brexit from happening.

Well, I've heard it all before, Julia.  Let's just remember who our last prime minister was for a moment.  108 times she said we are leaving on March the 29th.  She also repeatedly picked up and used the line, no deal is better than a bad deal.  She even put it in the Tory manifesto.  And we trusted the Conservative Party to deliver.  And look what happened.  You're asking me to trust Boris Johnson, who's pretty much saying the same things that she said.  Remember this.  Twice, Boris voted against the withdrawal agreement, saying it would reduce us to a vassal state, effectively becoming a colony of the European Union.  Then at the third time of asking, what did Boris do?  He voted for it.  If the Brexit party wasn't here, I think Boris would be very tempted to sell us out on a reheated version of Mrs May's treaty.  Without the Brexit party, there will never be a proper Brexit.

OK, let's say there's no electoral pact.  Let's say we end up with a general election and the vote gets bit.  Are you, in your fight for Brexit, are you willing to take the risk, in your point of view, of having no Brexit?  A Jeremy Corbyn-led government, a second referendum they've said they would try and negotiate to do and then weirdly have a second referendum in which they would possibly campaign for Remain and not the deal, which no one's got work out.  But would you be willing to risk a Corbyn government and no Brexit?

I'm not prepared to risk being sold out for the new European treaty that is the withdrawal agreement that will leave us arguably in a worse place than staying members of the European Union.  I want Brexit, a clean Brexit, so that we're an independent country.  And if Boris comes to that point of view, I should be delighted.  And I've already said, Julie, I've already said that to the 28 members of the ERG, who three times voted against that treaty.  We will not stand against any of them.  We will actually encourage people to work for them and support them.  That offer is open to other Conservative MPs as well.  I cannot do more than I'm doing to try and help people who want to get a proper Brexit.  Let's see what Boris decides to do.
Is it for you, just finally, is it all or nothing?  We get a proper Brexit or we don't have any Brexit at all and you would rather remain?

I just think if we were to sign up to that withdrawal agreement, even without the backstop, it would lead to years and years of acrimony, an incessant campaign for us to rejoin the European Union, and the humiliation of our nation to accept laws and court judgments from an organization in which we had no say whatsoever, and yet we're still paying 10 to 15 billion pounds every year.  It must not happen.  And if you look at public opinion, if you ask people a straightforward binary choice, do you want to leave?  with a clean Brexit, or do you want to extend and have a second referendum?  There is now a massive majority that prefer the first option over the second.  And I'm optimistic that we can get there.
